title: 198-B
statement: B. Jumping on Wallstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutVasya plays a computer game with ninjas. At this stage Vasya's ninja should get out of a deep canyon.The canyon consists of two vertical parallel walls, their height isnmeters. Let's imagine that we split these walls into1meter-long areas and number them with positive integers from1tonfrom bottom to top. Some areas are safe and the ninja can climb them. Others are spiky and ninja can't be there. Let's call such areasdangerous.Initially the ninja is on the lower area of the left wall. He can use each second to perform one of the following actions:climb one area up;climb one area down;jump to the opposite wall. That gets the ninja to the area that is exactlykmeters higher than the area he jumped from. More formally, if before the jump the ninja is located at areaxof one wall, then after the jump he is located at areax+kof the other wall.If at some point of time the ninja tries to get to an area with a number larger thann, then we can assume that the ninja got out of the canyon.The canyon gets flooded and each second the water level raises one meter. Initially the water level is at the lower border of the first area. Ninja cannot be on the area covered by water. We can assume that the ninja and the water "move in turns" — first the ninja performs some action, then the water raises for one meter, then the ninja performs one more action and so on.The level is considered completed if the ninja manages to get out of the canyon.After several failed attempts Vasya started to doubt whether it is possible to complete the level at all. Help him answer the question.InputThe first line contains two integersnandk(1 ≤n,k≤ 105) — the height of the canyon and the height of ninja's jump, correspondingly.The second line contains the description of the left wall — a string with the length ofncharacters. Thei-th character represents the state of thei-th wall area: character "X" represents a dangerous area and character "-" represents a safe area.The third line describes the right wall in the same format.It is guaranteed that the first area of the left wall is not dangerous.OutputPrint "YES" (without the quotes) if the ninja can get out from the canyon, otherwise, print "NO" (without the quotes).ExamplesInput7 3---X--X-X--XX-OutputYESInput6 2--X-X-X--XX-OutputNONoteIn the first sample the ninja should first jump to the right wall, then go one meter down along the right wall, then jump to the left wall. The next jump can get the ninja from the canyon.In the second sample there's no way the ninja can get out of the canyon.

processed.result: A character needs to climb out of a canyon with two walls.  The walls have safe and dangerous areas. The character can climb up or down one area at a time, or jump to the other wall a fixed distance. The water level rises one area each turn.  Determine if the character can escape the canyon.

You are given a canyon with two parallel walls, each $n$ meters high.  The walls are divided into 1-meter sections, and some sections are safe ("-") and some are dangerous ("X").

A ninja starts at the bottom of the left wall.  The ninja can:

* Climb one section up.
* Climb one section down.
* Jump to the opposite wall, landing $k$ sections higher than the starting section.

The water level rises one meter each second, starting at the bottom of the canyon. The ninja cannot be in a section covered by water.

The ninja wins if they reach a section higher than $n$ on either wall.

Determine if the ninja can escape the canyon.

**Input:**

* Two integers, $n$ and $k$ ($1 \le n, k \le 10^5$), representing the canyon height and jump height.
* A string of length $n$ representing the left wall ( "-" for safe, "X" for dangerous).
* A string of length $n$ representing the right wall.

**Output:**

* "YES" if the ninja can escape, "NO" otherwise.
